page.title: 09Housing in Colwall
page.content: According to the Domesday Book, Colwall (or Colewelle as it was then called) was a manor owned by the Bishop of Hereford. It seems to have been a well-ordered community, with no waste-land, a comfortable amount of meadow land, and enough arable land for 12 ploughs. The oldest houses in the village now are farm houses and timber-framed. Much of the farmland in the village has been built over with modern development. Colwall is now regarded as a very desirable place to live. It has a population in excess of 2000, many of them commuting to work in Worcester, Malvern and the West Midlands. In addition many retired people have come here and the value of property has become such that young married people cannot afford to buy houses here. This has created a social imbalance in the life of the village.
